title: Opinion | ‘The Godfather’ Was a Huge Risk. Robert Evans Said Yes Anyway.
text:
Appraising the contribution of the former Paramount Pictures executive Robert Evans is an act complicated not, as some may argue, by the well- and less-known facts and rumors of his private life — the cocaine, the women, the murder of one of the investors in a movie Mr. Evans produced, “The Cotton Club” (he was not charged) — but by the very complicated definition of “producer.” A producer and friend once told me, “The producer is the person who would do anything to get the movie made — and does.”

For several years Mr. Evans, who died on Saturday at 89, stood in the role of a studio head while playing the part of a relentless producer who would do anything to get the movie made — and did, many times, to the point of ruining marriages.

And many times, the movies he made were among Hollywood’s greatest ever.

“The Godfather,” “Chinatown” — no one would argue against them. But one might ask, “How responsible was Robert Evans for their greatness?” That is the right question. I don’t mean to be coy or opaque, but the answer is, paradoxically, entirely and not at all. Mr. Evans was not at all responsible to a degree that I think is easy to see: Great movies are great art made by great artists, and he was no artist. As much as he tried, somewhat pitifully, to flaunt the latent producer in him and claim credit for Francis Ford Coppola’s tremendous postproduction effort on “The Godfather,” the truth was the victory belonged, of course, to the director (and Mr. Coppola’s team at the production company American Zoetrope).

But — and here’s the other half of the paradox — Mr. Evans, the head of production, said yes to it. “Yes” is only one word, but when you’re running Paramount at a time when the industry is in serious financial decline and trying to decide whether you’re going to release a very long cut of a gangster movie (with an unknown for a leading man) that wasn’t really a gangster movie, “yes” is a very expensive word indeed.
description: The former Paramount Pictures executive wasn’t an artist, but he recognized artistry (and commercial potential) in others.
